title: Song of Solomon Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Song of Solomon chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Song of Solomon Chapter 3.

questions.question: Where did the speaker seek the one whom her soul loves by night?
questions.correctAnswer: On her bed
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth' as stated in Song of Solomon 3:1.

questions.question: What did the speaker decide to do after not finding him on her bed?
options: Rise and go about the city in the streets
questions.correctAnswer: Rise and go about the city in the streets
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I will rise now, and go about the city in the streets, and in the broad ways I will seek him' as found in Song of Solomon 3:2.

questions.question: Who found the speaker while she was seeking her beloved in the city?
questions.correctAnswer: The watchmen
questions.explanation: She says, 'The watchmen that go about the city found me' in Song of Solomon 3:3.

questions.question: What did the speaker do when she found him whom her soul loves?
options: Held him and would not let him go
questions.correctAnswer: Held him and would not let him go
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I held him, and would not let him go' in Song of Solomon 3:4.

questions.question: To whom did the speaker say she would not let her love go until she brought him?
questions.correctAnswer: Into my mother's house
questions.explanation: She states, 'until I had brought him into my mother's house' in Song of Solomon 3:4.

questions.question: What charge does the speaker give to the daughters of Jerusalem?
options: Do not stir up or awake my love till he please
questions.correctAnswer: Do not stir up or awake my love till he please
questions.explanation: The speaker charges, 'that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please' in Song of Solomon 3:5.

questions.question: How is the one coming out of the wilderness described?
options: Like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
questions.correctAnswer: Like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
questions.explanation: He is described 'like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense' in Song of Solomon 3:6.

questions.question: Whose bed is described in Song of Solomon 3:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon's
questions.explanation: The bed is described as 'Solomon's' in Song of Solomon 3:7.

questions.question: How many valiant men are about Solomon's bed?
questions.correctAnswer: Threescore
questions.explanation: There are 'threescore valiant men' about the bed according to Song of Solomon 3:7. Threescore means sixty.

questions.question: What do all the valiant men hold, according to Song of Solomon 3:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Swords
questions.explanation: They 'all hold swords, being expert in war' as described in Song of Solomon 3:8.

questions.question: True or False: King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 3:9 states, 'King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.'

questions.question: True or False: The pillars of Solomon's chariot were made of gold.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The pillars were made of silver, not gold, as stated in Song of Solomon 3:10.

questions.question: True or False: The bottom of Solomon's chariot was made of gold.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 3:10 says, 'the bottom thereof of gold.'

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon with the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his _______, and in the day of the gladness of his heart.'
questions.correctAnswer: espousals
questions.explanation: The verse in Song of Solomon 3:11 says, 'in the day of his espousals.'

questions.question: What is the covering of Solomon's chariot made of?
questions.correctAnswer: Purple
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 3:10 states, 'the covering of it of purple.'

medium.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Song of Solomon Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling lost and is seeking the Lord earnestly. Based on Song of Solomon 3:1-2, what biblical truth about prayer and seeking God would you share?
options: Diligently seek the Lord both day and night, even if you do not immediately find Him.
Only pray when you feel God's presence clearly.
Wait passively for God to reveal Himself without searching.
Seek worldly comfort first before seeking God.
questions.correctAnswer: Diligently seek the Lord both day and night, even if you do not immediately find Him.
questions.explanation: The passage in Song of Solomon 3:1-2 shows the beloved seeking her love by night and rising to seek him in the city, demonstrating persistent, active seeking. This teaches the importance of persistent prayer and devotion even when God seems distant.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 3:4 teach us about perseverance in pursuing our spiritual relationships?
options: Hold firmly to the Lord once you find Him and do not let go until He brings you to a place of spiritual security.
Give up if you don’t find God quickly.
Seek others besides God to satisfy your soul.
Ignore spiritual longings and focus on practical needs only.
questions.correctAnswer: Hold firmly to the Lord once you find Him and do not let go until He brings you to a place of spiritual security.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes holding the beloved and not letting him go until brought into the mother’s house. Spiritually, this encourages believers to cling to God steadfastly and faithfully, trusting Him to bring them into His protection and provision.

questions.question: A believer is worried about disturbing others in their spiritual growth. According to Song of Solomon 3:5, what counsel would you offer about timing in spiritual matters?
options: Do not rush or force spiritual growth; wait for God’s timing.
Push others aggressively to grow faster in faith.
Focus only on your own growth without regard to others.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rush or force spiritual growth; wait for God’s timing.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 charges the daughters of Jerusalem not to stir or awake love until it pleases. This illustrates the biblical principle of respecting God’s timing in spiritual matters and growth.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 3:6-8 reflect the importance of spiritual protection and vigilance in the life of a believer?
options: Be alert and protected spiritually, as the valiant men with swords guard the beloved.
Ignore spiritual attacks because God will protect you automatically.
Avoid all responsibility for your spiritual defense.
Depend solely on human strength without seeking God’s help.
questions.correctAnswer: Be alert and protected spiritually, as the valiant men with swords guard the beloved.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe Solomon’s bed guarded by valiant men holding swords at night, symbolizing the need for spiritual vigilance and protection against attacks or temptations.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and honoring God’s provision can be drawn from Song of Solomon 3:9-10 describing Solomon’s chariot and its materials?
options: Use God’s blessings with gratitude and honor Him by investing in what glorifies Him.
Hoard wealth without regard for God’s purposes.
Use wealth selfishly for personal gain only.
Ignore the blessings God gives and focus on worldly status.
questions.correctAnswer: Use God’s blessings with gratitude and honor Him by investing in what glorifies Him.
questions.explanation: The detailed description of Solomon’s chariot with precious materials symbolizes valuing and honoring God’s provision, encouraging believers to be faithful stewards who glorify God with their resources.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 3:11 emphasize the importance of rejoicing in God’s blessings within the community of believers?
options: Celebrate God’s blessings together as a joyful community of faith.
Keep blessings private and do not share them.
questions.correctAnswer: Celebrate God’s blessings together as a joyful community of faith.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 invites the daughters of Zion to behold Solomon crowned with gladness, showing the value of communal celebration and encouragement in God’s blessings.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with patience in waiting on the Lord’s timing. Based on the entire chapter, what practical advice does Song of Solomon 3 offer?
options: Continue seeking earnestly but wait respectfully for God’s perfect timing.
Give up if God seems silent.
Seek help from worldly sources instead.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue seeking earnestly but wait respectfully for God’s perfect timing.
questions.explanation: Throughout the chapter, persistent seeking (verses 1-2), but also the charge not to stir love till it pleases (verse 5), teach believers to balance earnest seeking with patient waiting on God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 3:3, it is appropriate to ask spiritual leaders or guardians if they have seen or encountered the Lord in our spiritual journey.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In verse 3, the speaker asks the watchmen if they have seen her beloved, illustrating that it is appropriate to seek guidance or confirmation from spiritual leaders during our spiritual journey.

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 3 teaches that spiritual love and devotion should be hurried and forced without regard to readiness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explicitly warns not to stir or awaken love until it pleases, teaching that spiritual love and growth should respect God’s timing and readiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Song of Solomon 3:7, Solomon’s bed is guarded by ______ valiant men to symbolize spiritual protection.
questions.correctAnswer: threescore
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that threescore (which means sixty) valiant men are about Solomon’s bed, symbolizing strong protection.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the watchmen holding swords in Song of Solomon 3:8 relate to Christian perseverance through trials?
options: It encourages believers to be prepared and vigilant against spiritual challenges.
It suggests avoiding all conflicts by hiding.
It promotes using physical weapons in spiritual matters.
It discourages any form of vigilance.
questions.correctAnswer: It encourages believers to be prepared and vigilant against spiritual challenges.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 describes the watchmen as experts in war holding swords for protection, symbolizing the need for spiritual readiness and perseverance during trials.

questions.question: A married couple wants to deepen their love and commitment. How does Song of Solomon 3:4 teach about the covenantal aspect of marriage?
options: Hold tightly to your spouse and cherish your covenant until fully established.
Let go easily when challenges arise.
Seek love outside the marriage covenant.
Ignore the spiritual significance of marriage.
questions.correctAnswer: Hold tightly to your spouse and cherish your covenant until fully established.
questions.explanation: The beloved holds her love and will not let him go until brought into her mother’s house, symbolizing the commitment and perseverance required in marriage.

questions.question: What does Song of Solomon 3:6 teach about the character and presence of Christ in our spiritual journey?
options: Christ comes like pillars of smoke, perfumed and majestic, symbolizing His holiness and glory.
Christ is only a silent observer.
questions.correctAnswer: Christ comes like pillars of smoke, perfumed and majestic, symbolizing His holiness and glory.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes a figure coming out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, indicating the majestic and holy presence of Christ in believers’ lives.

questions.question: How can the description of Solomon’s crown in Song of Solomon 3:11 encourage believers in humility and gratitude?
options: Recognize that all honor and blessing come from God, who crowns us with grace.
Seek crowns and honor for personal glory.
Ignore God’s role in blessings and take credit yourself.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that all honor and blessing come from God, who crowns us with grace.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 mentions Solomon’s crown given by his mother on the day of his espousals, teaching believers to be humble and grateful for God’s blessings and grace.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 3:1-3 teach about spiritual discipline and the importance of seeking God with integrity?
options: Seek God sincerely and inquire with honesty, even when answers seem delayed.
Pretend to seek God only when convenient.
Ignore the need for spiritual discipline.
Seek God only in public to gain approval.
questions.correctAnswer: Seek God sincerely and inquire with honesty, even when answers seem delayed.
questions.explanation: The beloved seeks him whom her soul loves with earnestness and asks the watchmen honestly if they have seen him, demonstrating integrity and discipline in spiritual pursuit.

hard.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Song of Solomon Chapter 3.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:1, what is the significance of the speaker seeking 'him whom my soul loveth' by night on her bed?
options: It symbolizes spiritual longing and the soul's pursuit of God as seen in Psalm 63
It illustrates a physical search for a lost object
It signifies a cultural practice of night vigils common in ancient Near East
It portrays a legal dispute about ownership
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual longing and the soul's pursuit of God as seen in Psalm 63
questions.explanation: The phrase 'sought him whom my soul loveth' in Song of Solomon 3:1 parallels the deep spiritual yearning expressed in Psalm 63:1, where the psalmist seeks God earnestly, symbolizing a soul’s intense desire for divine presence.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Song of Solomon 3:2 where the speaker rises and goes about the city seeking her beloved?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 3:2 shows parallelism as the speaker repeats the action of seeking her beloved both on her bed and through the city streets, emphasizing her persistent longing through balanced poetic structure.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:3, who are the 'watchmen' and what might their role symbolize in the cultural and historical context of ancient Jerusalem?
options: City guards symbolizing protection and vigilance over sacred love
questions.correctAnswer: City guards symbolizing protection and vigilance over sacred love
questions.explanation: The 'watchmen' in Song of Solomon 3:3 are city guards who patrol at night, symbolizing vigilance and protection, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern practice of guarding city gates and ensuring safety, especially over matters as precious as love.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Song of Solomon 3:4, the speaker holds her beloved and will not let him go until she brings him into her ________.
questions.correctAnswer: mother's house
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that she would not let him go until she had brought him into her mother's house, indicating a place of origin and familial connection, emphasizing intimacy and acceptance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the charge given in Song of Solomon 3:5 not to 'stir up, nor awake my love, till he please'?
options: It reflects the theme of divine timing and respect for personal readiness
It is a legal injunction for courtship
It instructs on agricultural practices of the season
It denotes a warning against political rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the theme of divine timing and respect for personal readiness
questions.explanation: The charge in 3:5 aligns with the biblical theme found in Ecclesiastes 3 and other wisdom literature about the importance of timing and waiting for the proper moment, emphasizing respect and patience in love and life.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:6, the beloved is described as coming out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke perfumed with myrrh and frankincense. What Old Testament imagery does this evoke?
options: The theophany of God at Mount Sinai in Exodus 19
The conquering king as in 2 Samuel 5
The exile of Israel to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The theophany of God at Mount Sinai in Exodus 19
questions.explanation: The imagery of smoke, myrrh, and frankincense recalls the Mount Sinai theophany in Exodus 19:18 where smoke and fire symbolize God's presence, suggesting the beloved’s majestic and divine-like entrance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 3:7-8, the valiant men surrounding Solomon's bed are unarmed and peaceful.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe sixty valiant men around Solomon's bed, each holding swords and being expert in war, indicating they are armed and prepared for defense, not peaceful or unarmed.

questions.question: What does the construction of King Solomon's chariot from the wood of Lebanon in Song of Solomon 3:9 signify in the historical and cultural context?
options: Use of the finest materials symbolizing royal power and wealth
A common method of chariot building in Egypt
A symbolic rejection of foreign resources
questions.correctAnswer: Use of the finest materials symbolizing royal power and wealth
questions.explanation: Lebanon cedar was prized in the ancient Near East for its quality and was often used in royal constructions, signifying Solomon’s wealth, craftsmanship, and political power as seen in 1 Kings 5.

questions.question: Which of the following materials is NOT mentioned as part of Solomon’s chariot in Song of Solomon 3:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Bronze
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 3:10 lists silver, gold, and purple as materials of the chariot, but does not mention bronze, highlighting the luxurious and precious nature of the chariot's construction.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the midst thereof being paved with love' (Song of Solomon 3:10) most likely symbolize in the context of ancient Near Eastern royal imagery?
options: The centrality of love and covenant in the king’s rule
A literal pavement of precious stones
questions.correctAnswer: The centrality of love and covenant in the king’s rule
questions.explanation: The phrase metaphorically places love at the heart of Solomon’s reign and relationship with his people, paralleling covenant themes found elsewhere in the Old Testament emphasizing loyalty and faithfulness.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:11, the daughters of Zion are called to behold Solomon with a crown. What does this event signify in ancient Israel’s royal and nuptial traditions?
options: The celebration of a royal wedding and public acknowledgment of kingship
A religious festival unrelated to marriage
questions.correctAnswer: The celebration of a royal wedding and public acknowledgment of kingship
questions.explanation: The verse references the day of Solomon’s espousals and the gladness of his heart, reflecting ancient Israel’s tradition of celebrating royal marriage as a political and spiritual event.

questions.question: How does the motif of seeking and finding in Song of Solomon 3:1-4 relate typologically to the New Testament’s portrayal of Christ and the Church?
options: It foreshadows Christ’s pursuit of the Church and the intimate union between them
It contrasts with Christ’s rejection by Israel
It illustrates a purely human romantic relationship
It depicts a legal contract between two parties
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ’s pursuit of the Church and the intimate union between them
questions.explanation: The beloved being sought and found and then held until brought into the mother’s house can be seen as a typology of Christ’s seeking of the Church (Ephesians 5:25-27), emphasizing covenantal love and union.

questions.question: What is the significance of the perfumes myrrh and frankincense mentioned in Song of Solomon 3:6 within the wider biblical sacrificial and worship context?
options: They represent costly offerings used in the Tabernacle and Temple worship
They were common household scents without religious meaning
They were used exclusively for embalming the dead
questions.correctAnswer: They represent costly offerings used in the Tabernacle and Temple worship
questions.explanation: Myrrh and frankincense were valuable incense offerings described in Exodus 30:34-38, used in worship and symbolizing holiness and divine presence, thus their mention here elevates the beloved’s portrayal.

questions.question: True or False: The description of Solomon’s chariot in Song of Solomon 3:9-10 includes silver pillars and a bottom of gold, highlighting a theme of earthly grandeur.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly describes silver pillars and a golden bottom of the chariot, emphasizing Solomon’s earthly wealth and royal splendor as part of the chapter’s imagery.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'pillars of smoke' in Song of Solomon 3:6 function as a metaphor within the poetic structure of the chapter?
options: It conveys the mysterious and majestic arrival of the beloved, enhancing the poem’s sensory and visual richness
It critiques the use of incense in religious practices
It describes a natural disaster in the city
It refers to the burning of the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: It conveys the mysterious and majestic arrival of the beloved, enhancing the poem’s sensory and visual richness
questions.explanation: The metaphor of 'pillars of smoke' evokes a majestic and almost divine presence, adding to the sensory imagery of the beloved’s arrival and fitting into the chapter’s poetic and symbolic structure.

theological.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Song of Solomon Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:1, what does the speaker do by night on her bed?
options: She seeks him whom her soul loves
questions.correctAnswer: She seeks him whom her soul loves
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states the speaker sought him whom her soul loves by night on her bed. This illustrates the soul's longing for the beloved, analogous to a believer's desire for Christ (Psalm 63:1; Luke 2:19; Philippians 3:10; Revelation 22:17).

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 3:4, what does the speaker do when she finds him whom her soul loves?
options: She holds him and will not let him go until brought into her mother's house
She greets him and sends him away
She asks him to leave the city
questions.correctAnswer: She holds him and will not let him go until brought into her mother's house
questions.explanation: The speaker's action of holding and not letting go until bringing him into her mother's house portrays a deep commitment and intimacy, symbolizing the believer's union with Christ (John 10:28; Hosea 2:19; Ephesians 5:27; Revelation 3:20).

questions.question: What is the charge given to the daughters of Jerusalem in Song of Solomon 3:5?
options: Do not stir up or awaken love until it pleases
Go forth and seek the beloved
Prepare a feast for the bridegroom
questions.correctAnswer: Do not stir up or awaken love until it pleases
questions.explanation: The charge not to stir up or awaken love emphasizes divine sovereignty in love and timing, paralleling God's control over salvation and covenant love (Ecclesiastes 3:1; Romans 9:15; Psalm 147:10; John 3:8).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:6, who is described as coming out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke?
options: The one perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
questions.correctAnswer: The one perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
questions.explanation: The figure coming like pillars of smoke perfumed with myrrh and frankincense symbolizes a majestic, divine-like presence, often interpreted messianically, reflecting Christ’s priestly and kingly attributes (Exodus 30:34-38; Psalm 45:8; Revelation 5:8; Isaiah 6:4).

questions.question: What is said about the men surrounding Solomon's bed in Song of Solomon 3:7-8?
options: Sixty valiant men, expert in war, each with a sword on his thigh
questions.correctAnswer: Sixty valiant men, expert in war, each with a sword on his thigh
questions.explanation: These men represent protection and vigilance, symbolizing God’s sovereign protection over the king and, typologically, Christ’s victory and the church’s security (Psalm 91:11-12; Isaiah 49:2; Ephesians 6:11-17; Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: What material is mentioned as used for making King Solomon's chariot in Song of Solomon 3:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Wood of Lebanon
questions.explanation: The wood of Lebanon is noted for its quality and beauty, representing splendor and strength, which aligns with the grandeur attributed to the Messiah’s reign (1 Kings 5:6; Psalm 92:12; Isaiah 60:13; Revelation 21:18).

questions.question: What adorns the pillars and bottom of King Solomon’s chariot according to Song of Solomon 3:10?
options: Pillars of silver and bottom of gold
Pillars of bronze and bottom of iron
Pillars of gold and bottom of silver
Pillars of stone and bottom of wood
questions.correctAnswer: Pillars of silver and bottom of gold
questions.explanation: Silver and gold symbolize purity and divine kingship, reflecting Christ’s glory and the church’s preciousness (Exodus 25:11; Psalm 68:13; Isaiah 60:17; Revelation 21:18-21).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'covering of purple' on Solomon's chariot mentioned in Song of Solomon 3:10?
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies royalty and wealth
questions.explanation: Purple dye was costly and reserved for royalty, indicating kingly authority, which typifies Christ as King of kings (Judges 8:26; Esther 8:15; Mark 15:17; Revelation 1:5-6).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the midst thereof being paved with love' in Song of Solomon 3:10 most likely represent?
options: The centrality of love in Solomon’s reign and the covenant
A literal pavement made of precious stones
The absence of conflict in the city
The foundation of justice and law
questions.correctAnswer: The centrality of love in Solomon’s reign and the covenant
questions.explanation: Love as the pavement signifies the foundational role of covenantal love, reflecting God’s love in salvation history and Christ’s love for the church (Deuteronomy 7:9; Jeremiah 31:3; Romans 5:8; 1 John 4:7-8).

questions.question: Who are invited to 'go forth and behold King Solomon with the crown' in Song of Solomon 3:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Daughters of Zion
questions.explanation: The daughters of Zion represent the people of God called to witness the king’s glory, foreshadowing the eschatological revelation of Christ and his bride (Isaiah 62:11; Zechariah 9:9; Matthew 21:5; Revelation 19:7).

questions.question: What is the significance of Solomon’s crown mentioned in Song of Solomon 3:11?
options: It symbolizes his official kingship and the joy of his espousals
It is a symbol of military conquest
It represents his wealth and riches
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes his official kingship and the joy of his espousals
questions.explanation: The crown marks Solomon’s legitimate kingship and the joyful occasion of his espousals, prefiguring Christ’s eternal kingship and the marriage supper of the Lamb (1 Samuel 16:12-13; Psalm 21:3; Isaiah 61:10; Revelation 19:7-9).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:3, to whom does the speaker address her question about the beloved?
options: The watchmen that go about the city
questions.correctAnswer: The watchmen that go about the city
questions.explanation: The watchmen are guardians of the city, to whom the speaker asks about the beloved, symbolizing spiritual watchfulness and the search for Christ (Nehemiah 4:13; Ezekiel 3:17; Mark 13:33-37; Revelation 3:3).

questions.question: What does the speaker mean by 'I sought him, but I found him not' in Song of Solomon 3:2?
options: She expresses a deep longing and temporary absence of the beloved
She gives up seeking the beloved
She is searching for a lost object
She is calling the watchmen to action
questions.correctAnswer: She expresses a deep longing and temporary absence of the beloved
questions.explanation: The repeated seeking and not finding portrays the soul’s intense desire and spiritual yearning for Christ, who sometimes seems absent but is always sought (Psalm 42:1-2; Lamentations 3:25; Luke 19:41; Hebrews 11:27).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 3:8, why do the valiant men hold their swords upon their thighs?
options: Because of fear in the night
questions.correctAnswer: Because of fear in the night
questions.explanation: Their readiness due to fear at night symbolizes vigilance against spiritual enemies, reminding believers of the need for watchfulness and readiness (Psalm 34:7; Isaiah 21:11-12; Ephesians 6:12-17; 1 Peter 5:8).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 3:5 appeal to creation in the charge to the daughters of Jerusalem?
options: By invoking the roes and hinds of the field
By calling upon the stars and moon
By referencing the mountains and rivers
By mentioning the birds of the air
questions.correctAnswer: By invoking the roes and hinds of the field
questions.explanation: Invoking roes and hinds ties the natural world to the covenantal plea, illustrating the harmony between creation and divine love, consistent with biblical imagery (Genesis 1:26-28; Psalm 104:10-18; Isaiah 35:6; Matthew 6:26).
